abstract: The world’s leading cellphone maker said it intended to cut costs by nearly 20 percent over three years as it transitions to mobile software made by its new partner, Microsoft.
snippet: The world’s leading cellphone maker said it intended to cut costs by nearly 20 percent over three years as it transitions to mobile software made by its new partner, Microsoft.
lead_paragraph: Nokia, the struggling market leader in mobile phones, said on Thursday that it intended to cut costs by nearly 20 percent over three years, a move that will most likely eliminate thousands of jobs as it enters an alliance with Microsoft.

headline.main: Despite Microsoft Partnership, Nokia Continues to Fade in Race With Rivals
headline.print_headline: Despite Microsoft Partnership, Nokia Continues to Fade in Race With Rivals
